newsitem.title: INDIA: India rupee ends steady at 35.88/89 against dollar.
newsitem.headline: India rupee ends steady at 35.88/89 against dollar.

text.p: The Indian rupee closed steady at 35.88/89 against the dollar on Monday, dealers said.
"It was an anticlimax of sorts," said a dealer. "Everyone expected the RBI (Reserve Bank of India) to be buying dollars today but they didn't."
Banks looking for signs of a pre-budget spurt in demand were also disappointed.
The leading Calcutta-based state-run bank was passive, buying dollars only from those who approached it.
As a result, the spot rupee, which touched a low of 35.9075 edged up to 35.8850, its highest level on Monday, dealers said.
The premia on the forward dollar continued to climb, reflecting genuine paying pressure from banks seeking to roll-over FCNR (foreign currrency non-resident) deposits.
"The current levels are good for payers," said the chief forex dealer at a leading bank in Bombay.
The fact that RBI has exhausted its positions in the forward dollar market initiated earlier this month also helped premia rise, dealers said.
The six month annualised premium closed at 7.47 percent, up from the earlier close of 7.13 percent, dealers said.
Some dealers expect a mild pre-budget tension and dollar covering beginning Wednesday. The budget is scheduled to be unveiled on Friday, February 28.

The government's ambitious projections for capital inflows during the Ninth Plan (1997-2002) could keep the rupee slightly overvalued in the long term "as it would encourage both imports and capital flow," NatWest Securities said in a research paper.
It expected the rupee to depreciate by about 5.0 percent to 38.64 against the dollar by the end of 1997/98 (April-March).

NatWest said it expected the trade deficit to worsen to $10.22 billion in 1997/98 from an estimated $8.18 billion in 1996/97. It said the trade deficit would be lower in 1996/97 from $18.94 billion in the previous year because of a slowdown in Indian imports.
"But we are expecting a revival in private consumption demand during 1997 and as a result, import demand should pick up during the second quarter of 1997/98," NatWest said.
